0.text: This is the Brain Zoo. Where the brain animals live.

3.text: There are some that you may recognize, such as:

7.text: Who is always telling you how everything will go wrong,

9.text: and you're shit, and no one ever loved you anyway.

14.text: Who insists that effort is boring, so don't do it.

18.text: Who recommends you end your own life.

22.text: The moose, who suggests at all times, that you should be doing more ketamine.

27.text: Might be a bit, specific, that last one...

29.text: Anyway, these guys are usually hiding under the surface, telling you, what's what,

33.text: but is there a way to quiet them down?

38.text: Imagine your mind is a big concert.

42.text: Who does all of the watching, and listening.

44.text: This is the core of your mind, right?

47.text: Just pure awareness.  You with a capital Y̲.

52.text: They represent all the sensations in your mind, good, and bad, and everything flowing in.

57.text: Sometimes you're eating a lovely sandwich, or hanging out with someone you think is a bit special,

61.text: and the orchestra plays a happy number.

64.text: Other times you get fired, or some

66.text: 𝐰𝐢𝐭𝐥𝐞𝐬𝐬 𝐝𝐢𝐜𝐤𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐝 𝐩𝐮𝐭 𝐬𝐮𝐠𝐚𝐫 𝐢𝐧 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐭𝐞𝐚!

69.text: And now the orchestra is playing quite a different tune, indeed.

72.text: The point is that the orchestra never stops.

75.text: They're always playing something or other in your mind, about

80.text: They never shut up. We're constantly swimming in thoughts.

84.text: And sometimes, the audience starts thinking, they are the orchestra.

87.text: that is the root of the problem with fear, and unpleasant emotions, it seems.

96.text: The funny thing is, that there are only a hundred chairs in the brain concert.

99.text: Now, on those days in life, when there's nothing to worry about, and stuff's going well,

106.text: There's nothing to fight against, you've got control of your own head.

110.text: But the real danger time is when you're afraid, or pissed off, like when you have to do something scary,

115.text: and the audience starts trying to run away.

117.text: But of course the orchestra doesn't like it when you try to run away.

120.text: So more move in, and play louder,

123.text: until the whole concert is 95% orchestra, and 5% poor audience,

128.text: and you lose control of your mind!

132.text: and Captain Dickhead McTerror just fills the vacuum for as long as you let him.

140.text: Well, who's really in control here?

147.text: Well it's the audience, right? They pay for the concert.

150.text: That's who everyone is here for, the part of your mind just observing everything.

154.text: If the audience don't like what's playing, they can just listen, for a while.

157.text: They're not personally responsible. They didn't write the music!

160.text: Besides, they know it's only music, anyway.

167.text: Reminding yourself over, and over, that mind nasties, are just noise.

172.text: Fear is just a shit orchestra.

174.text: And that watching it, instead of getting drawn in, is a very, very good way to kill it.

178.text: Same goes for all the other little bastards, in the brain zoo.

182.text: Meditation doesn't have to be performed sitting down cross-legged with an incense stick up your arse.

187.text: right before you're about to get up on stage, or do something else you're bothered by.

193.text: Observing, rather than getting drawn in, and freaking out.

196.text: This isn't easy to do, and humans have been working on it for thousands of years.

202.text: thoughts and sensations are only noise, in the first place.

205.text: They aren't You. You with a capital Y̲, that is.

209.text: The audience isn't the orchestra. If shit music is playing, they can just listen, and not pay.

214.text: And what happens, when people stop paying for bad orchestras?

217.text: Well they go out of business, eventually.

219.text: Until it's just one guy left on stage, playing crappy trombone.

222.text: And the only person he's harming, is himself.

231.text: If you really wanted to find out where that sense of "Youness" is coming from in the first place,

236.text: well, let's go on a little mental adventure.

241.text: Well first let's forget your life, and identity for a second, right?

246.text: Then let's try to ignore all the sensations in your head.

249.text: All your desires, and daydreams, and phobias, and memories,

254.text: because that isn't really you either.

256.text: And let's just go right to the back of your mind, where 'real you' lives.

259.text: But when we get there, it's just empty space, right?

262.text: There's no sign of a self, or a real identity.  There's no one home.

270.text: Not if you take everything else away.

272.text: I hope, like me, you find that

277.text: and I'm not sure what that means.

278.text: But sometimes it's nice to have a nice good old look at the wiring under the board, now and again.

283.text: To remind yourself that we are very, very weird machines.

287.text: Most of the time we just listen to the orchestra and do whatever it tells us to.

294.text: But with a bit of determination and practice,

297.text: plenty of people have gotten good at telling their audience to stay seated when something awful is going on.

302.text: Lots of links below about how to get started if you're interested.

306.text: I know this sounds a bit cult-y, but it isn't.

309.text: It's basically just recycled Buddism, without the frilly stuff.

312.text: But anyway, that is the idea of meditation, really.

315.text: To get you to a point where you can say,

320.text: And, "Alright, you compelling little drug moose,

324.text: 👉😎👉 let's go get some FUCKING ketamine!"
